The plugging is being done with the consent of the King. Average depth of wells is 4500 feet and drilling is difficult. The gas separators have been protected by walls, and such protection to the stab plant and other vital equipment is in hand. Bunsen Burners have been installed for the disposal of surplus gas and the venting of such gas to atmosphere is under consideration. Guards and patrols on the lease have not been increased since the War : these are under G-overnment control. Loading ghats are at A1 Khobar and at Port A1 Aziziyah, 7 miles to the South; the latter ghat is usually used as the haul by barge to Zellaq on Bahrein Island is shorter : there are two 15,000 barrel tanks at the jetty which it is not intended to sheath; even if these tanks were put out of action loading could continue though at a slower rate. The 3000 barrel Refinery at Has Tabura, 60 miles from Dhahran, is shut down : I did not visit it - It must contain much idle tankage. Staff at Dhahran is homogeneous, namely about 110 Americans : the only women are 2 nursing sisters. Stocks of food and drink are adequate meantime, but like B.A.P.C.O. a rationing scale is under consideration. C.A.S.O.C. have recently lost at sea half a years 1 supply of lub oil for themselves and the West coast of Arabia* The position regarding the supply of certain sizes of tyres is also causing anxiety. There is a shortage of drums for distribution of oil in Arabia, and it was intended to investigate the feasibility of drawing on the vast stocks of Italian returnables said to exist in Abyssinia and Eritrea. I returned to Bahrein by dhow on June 10th. On June 11th I visited the R.A.P. landing ground, and the Naval Base where I met the officers in charge. ^ Nothing of importance emerged in my discussions with these ox-icers* I also met Major Hewitt, Defence officer of the Persian G-ulf, whose title is likely soon to be changed. It is probable that an Indian infantry Batalion will be posted to Bahrein, the majority of which will be stationed near the Refinery. I took the opportunity of telling B.A.P.C.O. and C.A.S.O.C* of Indian needs of material and asked them to advise me if they could assist. I left Bahrein by air on June 12th and arrived Basra that evening : several evacuees from the Burma Oilfields v/ere aboard en route to Abadan. BASRA . On June 13th I called upon Mr. Lock of the M.W.T. and the R.E. to discuss supply and transport of bricivs to Bahrein and left Basra for Bagdad that night. BAGDAD. 16.6.42

physicalDescription.extent: Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 7; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains a report by Hugo Salvin Bowlby, Petroleum Department representative in Baghdad, on his visit to Abadan, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and Basra, forwarded by Petroleum Department to the India Office. The report describes visits to oil fields in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia, in June 1942.
